title: World Catching Up With China on Surveillance Tech
text:
WASHINGTON—China leads the world in facial-recognition and other new surveillance technologies, with its own government using the tools at home and Huawei Technologies Co. exporting them globally, according to a new report by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

But other countries are adopting similar technologies, according to the think tank’s report, which is based on research by a former State Department official in the Obama administration.

At least 75 countries around the world, from the U.S. to Brazil, Germany, India, and Singapore, host artificial intelligence to surveil citizens, the report said—a wider footprint than previously documented.

Huawei is leading the charge, providing surveillance technology in 50 countries, far more than its nearest competitor, the report says, adding “no other company comes close.”

In many cases, however, governments are using U.S. technology alongside Huawei’s. The top U.S. firm identified in the report was International Business Machines Corp. , which sold surveillance technology in 11 countries. IBM provides governments with so-called smart-cities technology to monitor a city and analyze data.

IBM and Huawei didn’t immediately respond to requests for comment Monday.

Defenders of facial recognition and other surveillance tools note how they can be used for good, protecting citizens from terrorist attacks and other threats.

“China is exporting surveillance tech to liberal democracies as much as it is targeting authoritarian markets,” showing how democracies are exporting it and using it as well as authoritarian regimes, wrote report author Steven Feldstein, now an associate professor at Boise State University. “Likewise, companies based in liberal democracies…are actively selling sophisticated equipment.”

WSJ's Jason Bellini talks to Real Networks CEO Robert Glaser about his company's facial recognition technology that is being used in schools and retail stores. The surprise? Glaser himself has privacy concerns and is calling for regulation of the technology.

The report relies on Mr. Feldstein’s review of news reports and other information from 176 countries, which he posted in a publicly available database. The survey included countries, cities and other governments as well as quasi-public entities such as airports.

He counted 64 countries where government entities have purchased facial-recognition technology that uses cameras and photo databases; 56 countries where authorities have used “smart cities” technology, such as sensors and body cameras that collect information analyzed at a command center; and 53 countries where authorities are using “smart policing” systems that analyze data and make predictions about future crimes.

“The good news is that there is ample time to initiate a much-needed public debate about the proper balance between AI technology, government surveillance, and the privacy rights of citizens,” writes Mr. Feldstein. “But as these technologies become more embedded in governance and politics, the window for change will narrow.”

description: China leads the world in facial-recognition and other new surveillance technologies, according to a new report by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.
